1331.content:
In the days following her father's heart attack, Laurie had found herself doing some serious soul-searching. The very idea would've made her brother's friends laugh - since when did she have a soul to search? It surprised her sometimes, too, but given the circumstances, it was no surprise. She was scared. She'd basically given her dad a heart attack. Because she married Fez.

Fez had been about to be deported because his visa would expire once he graduated high school and the exchange program ended. She hadn't really taken an interest in the situation until the camping trip and they had sex in the van. It hadn't been bad. Better than a lot of the losers she'd done it with, but not talented either. He'd confided in her that he'd only lost his virginity only a month ago to a coworker at the DMV, so he had inexperience as an excuse, but it hadn't really been all that interesting. Still, they'd wound up talking through the night, and so she offered the idea of a quickie marriage in town. He'd been dubious at first, but then they had sex a second time, and it seemed more appealing to him.

She'd genuinely been trying to help him. And the shock gave Red a heart attack.

Soon, an entire week had gone by, and she was still miserable. She had stayed at home in her old room. Thankfully, Fez had given her space. For being an absolute perv, he was still a decent guy. She hid herself from the others for most of that time, only coming down for dinner. Red was doing well. He just had to stay for observation. If anyone was angry at her, it faded very quickly. Eric had a few snide comments about how she'd almost killed their dad, but she didn't have the energy to respond to them, so he must've figured she was feeling guilty and let it go.

She barely ate during that week, so one night, when everyone had gone to sleep, she scrounged together whatever money she had hidden around the house - and some Eric had hidden around the house - and went out. She was starving, but she wasn't really up for leftovers. She strolled around Point Place - which was pretty lowkey as far as crime was concerned - and approached the nearest Fatso Burger. It was still an hour before they closed, so she went in and ordered a double bacon cheeseburger with fries and a large milkshake. She flashed her bra at the cashier, ensuring her usual discount, and took everything to an outside table and ate away, enjoying the summer air.

As she ate, she thought about what was happening around her. Eric and Donna were going away to college soon, Hyde and Kelso were still fighting over Jackie, and she was married to Fez. Good god, she was pathetic. The thought just made her cram more food into her mouth. The grease tasted so good right now. The minutes passed, and soon, she had finished everything. She took a few last sips of milkshake, getting as much as she could. She needed to get as much as she could so as to fill the gaping hole in her soul right now.

Throwing her trash away and returning the tray, she still felt empty and depressed, so she went to a twenty-four-hour grocery store with the money she had left and got a pint of cookie dough ice cream. Another slip of the bra ensured she got it half off, and she made her way home, getting a spoon out of the drawer and taking it back to her room. She sighed tiredly as she practically inhaled the thing before lying down to get some sleep. She patted her stomach, appreciative of the fullness settling inside it.

When Laurie came out of her bedroom the next morning, she found that her mother was doing what she always did in times of stress. She was cooking. She stopped a bit short in the doorway at the massive piles of breakfast food that lined the table and counter. And there was still more going on, with Kitty frying bacon and scrambling more eggs, with a stack of pancakes piling up as well.

Kitty turned and saw her. "Oh, Laurie, good. Just in time for breakfast! I'm just finishing up here!"

Laurie stared at the frenzy. She looked past her mother and saw Hyde, Kelso, Jackie and Fez were working on their own sections of breakfast. She had to admit it all looked rather good. Wordlessly, she got a plate and allowed Kitty to pile it all on. Five pancakes, a pile of scrambled eggs, a handful of bacon and a cinnamon roll for luck. She got a glass of orange juice and joined the others at the table.

"She's been cooking nonstop for the last hour," Hyde filled her in.

"No complaints here," Fez chirped. "Your mother cooks edible heaven."

Laurie had to agree. The food was delicious. With her still feeling down about everything, food was a great comfort right now.

When Kitty finished cooking, she announced she was going on ahead to the hospital to check on Red. "Steven, tell Eric when you see him that he'll need to take the Vista Cruiser down and pick him up while I'm still working."

"Got it," Hyde replied.

As she left, Laurie finished her eggs and started in on the pancakes. Kelso got up and went to the fridge, getting out some raw eggs. She rolled her eyes at the sight of him. He was wearing a jogging suit with a sweatband. He was going to impress Jackie by drinking eggs raw like in one of those dumb "Rocky" movies. She couldn't help but laugh when he downed them in one gulp, only to be reminded by Jackie that he was allergic to eggs. He would have to go to the hospital now. When Eric came over, he agreed to take him along with Hyde, leaving her alone with Fez and Jackie and the remainder of breakfast.

"So...," she said with a tiny smirk. "You're seriously trying to choose between those clowns?"

Jackie scowled. "I'll have you know I've already decided."

"Please tell me it's not egg boy."

"No, it's Steven. I don't know what it is about him, but... I don't know..." She turned away, a bit embarrassed.

Laurie shrugged and started in on the bacon. "Well, good luck. Whichever loser you end up with is a lucky guy."

Jackie looked surprised, but smiled all the same. "You know, for a lying skank who stole Michael away from me, you're okay." She put her plate int he sink and left.

Now she was just with Fez. He sat down next to her. "Can I get anything for you, my darling?"

Laurie rolled her eyes. "Fez, come on. Just because we're married doesn't mean you have to do stuff for me."

"You have saved me! You helped me to stay in the country! I would do anything for you!"

Laurie looked at her empty plate. How'd she eaten all of that so fast. "... Can you get me some more pancakes?"

"Of course, my dear." Fez eagerly grabbed her plate and put the remaining pancakes on it, which was twice as many as she'd had before. She looked at the stack worriedly, but she took one look at Fez's cheerful face and felt another surge of guilt. This guy was so grateful for the pathetic shotgun wedding it made her feel bad for everything again. She felt the emptiness again and proceeded to scarf them down.

"So, what shall we do with our day, my wife?"

Laurie groaned internally. "Fez, look, my dad's coming home from the hospital..."

"My father-in-law. I cannot wait."

"Fez, he's still pissed off at you for marrying me."

"Why? He should be grateful. We all know your reputation."

That didn't help. Laurie felt another wave of emptiness in her soul, and assumed it was her stomach. She ate another pancake. "Whatever. You need to be away from here. Otherwise he might kill you."

Fez now looked afraid. "Do you think so?"

"Fez, he was in the war. He know how."

He gulped and made to stand, "Are you sure you'll be fine here by yourself?"

She ate another pancake. "I think I'll survive."

"Very well. I shall go on the lamb. Call me when it's safe to come back." He leaned over and gave her a quick kiss on the cheek and left through the sliding door before she could properly react. She was momentarily stunned by the kiss, but any warmth she got from it once again turned into shame. This poor guy was all set to make this a proper marriage, and she was... well, she was Laurie Forman. The ultimate skank.

The unbuttoned her jeans and gorged herself. She had to distract herself from the guilt. She finished the pancakes, then went up to the counter and ate all the remaining bacon and eggs, then a few cinnamon rolls, and then gulped down from pitcher of orange juice until she just couldn't anymore. She sat down on one of the stools at the counter leaned back, feeling the lump that was her stomach under her tank top, which was now feeling a little tight.

"Ohhhhhh....," she groaned. "That was... tooooo much..."

Deciding that was enough for one day, she heaved herself down and made it back to her room. She laid down and pulled the blanket back over her head, listening to her stomach gurgle.

She woke up a few hours later to the sound of the kitchen door closing. She heard voices downstairs, and she knew Red was home. Swallowing down her worry, she got up and straightened herself up. Hopefully, she wasn't going to give him another heart attack on the spot just from wrinkled clothes. Taking a deep breath, she went downstairs and into the living room just as her family entered.

Red froze when he saw her. She gave him a weak smile and waved nervously. "Hi, Daddy...," she ventured.

He looked at her for a long moment before smiling that fatherly smile and holding his arms out to her. "Come on down, kitten. Everything's fine."

Sighing with relief, she came downstairs and hugged him. "Oh, I'm so glad you're okay. I'm so sorry about... you know, almost killing you and stuff."

"Oh, that's not your fault, kitten. It's that damn foreigner."

Laurie looked up at him. "... What?"

"Just wait until I get my hands on him. I can't believe he would take advantage of you like that. The way he just came in here and tricked you, the sneaky little -- ."

"Dad, hold on, time out," Laurie said, quickly disentangling herself from him. "That's not what happened."

Red's brow furrowed in confusion. "Well, how else could it happen?"

Laurie noticed Eric roll his eyes disparagingly but ignored him for now. "It was my idea."

"... Your idea? It was your idea to marry that filthy little -- "

"Hey! Knock it off! That's my green card husband you're talking about! Look, during the camping trip, we got to talking, we... had some fun together..." Again, ignoring the expression on Eric's face, which was nausea this time. "... and the more he talked about it, the more I felt bad for him, and I had nothing else to do, so I thought - hey, this'll be my good deed for the next ten years." She finished with a lame shrug.

Red looked like he was going to burst a blood vessel. "How could you do something so stupid?!"

"Dad, I'm sorry, okay? I'm sorry it almost killed you! But Fez needed help, and Donna and Jackie weren't about to do it, and I felt sorry for him! It was out of pity, okay?"

He still looked pissed, so Kitty came over to try to calm him down. "Okay, Red, let's take it easy. We just need to get you upstairs and lie you down..."

"How can she just waltz in here and act like this is okay?" Red demanded. "How the hell am I supposed to be okay being married to that dirty little - !"

"Dad, come on," Eric interrupted. "Look, yes, Laurie and Fez being married is weird and sudden, and okay, so it almost killed you, but you know what? She could definitely do a lot worse. It could've been Kelso. Besides, it's not like they're going to stay married. They just need to clear it with the government so Fez can get his new visa and they'll get divorced. Right, Laurie?"

Laurie nodded quickly, for once relieved her little brother had been conceived. "Exactly! It's temporary!"

Red looked between them for a few moments before deciding to calm down. "Okay... Fine... I'll let it go. But you'd better keep him out of this house, understood."

Eric blinked. "Er... well..."

"Come on, Red," Kitty said, aiming him for the stairs. "Let's get you to bed."

Red grumbled a little more as he allowed himself to be guided. "Fine..."

Discussions then turned to how Kitty was going to have to work extra hours at the hospital until Red was either well enough to go back to work or find another job. She tried to get Eric to do a few chores, but he reminded her he was moving out soon to Madison with Donna. This prompted a brief argument between them about Eric supposedly abandoning the family, but Red took his turn to be the sane one and faked another heart attack to distract them.

Once their parents were upstairs, Laurie made to go past Eric to head to the kitchen, but he caught her arm. "Hey, thanks for clearing things up with Fez. I know you don't actually like him, but... well, thanks."

Laurie smirked. "Oh, don't worry about it. Last thing I need right now is for dad to make me a widow at age twenty-four."

Eric smiled gratefully before leaving. It was so rare they had friendly moments like that, they decided to just leave it at that. Relieved the confrontation was over, Laurie headed into the kitchen. She was hungry again.

Looking into the fridge, she found more of Kitty's meals that had been cooked during her stressful period, so she proceeded to unload a pan of meatloaf and poured some mustard on it. Deciding not to bother with cutting off a piece, she stuck a fork in and just ate off of it. There was just something so satisfying about sitting back and enjoying some food. It was something she had denied herself for so long. She enjoyed herself, just eating away at the chunk of meat for a good thirty minutes until it was finally gone. Stifling a burp, she put the dish in the sink and headed for her room. She patted her stomach, enjoying the fullness she so rarely allowed herself.
133111.title: Red comes home, and Laurie must face him

choices: Laurie can't figure out cooking, which results in nightly take out
Laurie is eventually forced to get a job to help the family.
1331112.content:
Hanging out around the house basically comprised of her being bored and watching TV in the living room. With Red not allowed to do anything strenuous, Kitty was constantly rushing around doing chores. There were meals to cook, dishes to wash, laundry to do, and even a lawn to mow. So while Laurie vegetated on the couch for a couple of days, her mother was going round and round in a frenzied state, usually with a laundry basket in her hands.

It was a little depressing to watch, so Laurie tried moving to other locations in the house, but she couldn't quite find a place where her mother didn't do any work. She was constantly cleaning as well, so the bedrooms were out. The kitchen was a constant source of cooking, so that didn't help. Even the basement wasn't safe, as it was home to the washer and dryer.

And that's where she found her mother passed out one night, asleep amongst a pile of dirty clothes and an overturned hamper. She gently reached over and tapped her mom's foot, waking her up. "Fabric softener!" she yelped as she jolted awake, sending socks everywhere.

"Mom...?"

"Oh... Laurie, sorry. Must've dropped off." She checked her watch. "Oh, god, I'm late for work. Night's can be our busiest time. Lots of people stroke out after a big salty dinner." She got up and started to dust herself off. "Laurie, sweetie, I know you don't like to work or even, you know, be remotely helpful but... could you please...?"

Laurie rolled her eyes. "Yeah, fine. I'll do the laundry. Get going."

"Thank you, thank you!" she said, briefly kissing her on the cheek and running up the stairs. "There's food in the... Oh, who am I kidding. There's no food." And she was gone.

Laurie sighed and got to work on the laundry. She separated everything by color and fabric before starting the washer and putting in the detergent and baking soda and pouring everything in. Satisfied that everything was in motion, she plopped down on the couch, grabbing a discarded bag of chips that really hit the spot right about now. She enjoyed a round of "I Love Lucy" before the door opened and Eric and Donna came down.

"Hey, what're you up to?"

Laurie gestured at the washing machine. "Waiting for the laundry to finish."

"Why? Where's mom?"

"At work. Night shift."

"She's working again?"

"Well, with dad cooped up in the house, she's pulling extra hours."

Eric looked really conflicted in that moment. "She shouldn't have to do that. She's got enough work around here as it is."

"Tell me something I don't know. She's been cleaning, cooking... By the way, there's no food, so we should probably order take out. Pizza or Chinese?"

Eric rubbed his face tiredly. "I can't believe this... Our own mother is slaving away like this, and I'm about to go away to college and abandon them like this. I can't just leave them with no extra help."

Laurie looked affronted. "Uh, hello? Totally spending time doing laundry over here!" she reminded him, pointing at the busy washing machine.

"Oh, great, so you do one load of laundry, and everyone's supposed to be impressed?"

"I'll do all the laundry! I kind of have to if I want my good jeans ready by tomorrow..."

"And so you're going to do all the laundry while your mom does everything else?" Donna asked. "Do you even know how a vacuum works?"

"Of course I do!"

"Or how to do dishes?"

"Or how to do work?" Eric added.

She stood up to glare at him more effectively. "I know how to do all those things!"

"Then why don't you do all those things? Do all the housework so Mom isn't constantly rushing around all the time?"

Laurie realized she'd gotten trapped. She'd built herself up, and now she wasn't sure how to get out of it. "Well... I... could..."

"So you'll do it?"

"... Yeah, I guess...," she pouted, thudding back down on the couch again in disappointment.

Donna patted her patronizingly on the shoulder. "Well, it's either this or get an actual job."

Laurie groaned. "Oh, just go to college," she grumbled. "Anything to get rid of you two."

Eric smiled and patted her on the head. "Thanks, sis."

"Go to hell."

"Okay, it's either college or hell. Make up your mind."

Donna swatted him on the arm and they went upstairs. "We'll order a pizza," she assured her.

Laurie waved them off and waited for the laundry to finish.

At that moment, the shower curtain slid open and Fez stepped out, much to her surprise. "How long were you in there?"

"About an hour."

She made a face. "Were you waiting on Eric and Donna to start making out?"

Fez nodded guiltily. "Yeah, well... I was going to leave, but then I started watching Lucy with you and I got transfixed. She is a black-and-white comedy goddess."

Laurie couldn't help but smirk. "Yeah, she's pretty cool." She heard a ding come from the far wall and realized the laundry was done. She sighed in annoyance before getting up and opening it up to switch the load over to the dryer.

Fez watched her from the arm of the couch. "I think it's really nice of you to help Miss Kitty. That poor woman needs a break. When I came down here, I heard her muttering about an evil washing machine trying to devour her while she slept."

Laurie shrugged, quietly pleased that someone was noting her hard work. "Yeah, well... Sometimes you gotta do what you gotta do. If I want clean clothes, I'm going to have to do it myself."

"That is so selfless."

"I know, right?" She was so glad someone saw things from her point of view. "Anyway, they're ordering pizza up there."

"Yes, I heard. Don't worry. I have M&M's to tide us over."

She finished loading the dryer, feeling the first signs of perspiration on her forehead. "Oh that sounds like heaven right now. I'm starving."

He held out the bag. "My candy is your candy."

"Really?"

Fez shrugged. "We are married, after all."

She couldn't help but smile at the sentiment. Okay, so she could've chosen worse guys to get hitched to. Free candy was always a plus. She sat down with him on the sofa and took his offering of multi-colored candies, and that's where they stayed until a thirty minutes later when the pizza came.
1331112.title: Laurie helps out more around the house

13311121.content:
As the days wore on, things around the house began to quiet down a little. Laurie accepted the fact that she was going to have to help out around the house a lot more, especially with Eric going away to college. Although Hyde wasn't really chipping in much housework, he was willing to sign over his paycheck from working at the restaurant every other week to help pay the bills, and Fez felt he ought to repay the Formans for not killing him by helping out where and when he could, like mowing the lawn.

The lack of chores insured that Kitty had more time for other things, including cooking Red his "heart friendly" dinner. There had been a minor dispute over Red's diet, so Kitty had decided to go on it with him. Potato chips, heavy creams, cheese, salty foods were all out. Of course, she didn't handle the lack of alcohol very well. Still, no one was complaining. The kids were more than happy to take care of the unhealthy foods. And seeing as how she was working around the house all the time, Laurie found herself snacking more than any of them. At one point, she found herself absently sipping away at a small carton of whipping cream. She was momentarily disgusted before realizing it was actually pretty good and finishing the rest of it.

One little detail was troubling her, however. Kitty only made dinner for Red during the day before putting it in the oven for reheating later. The kids were left to fend for themselves. Laurie, however, was a terrible cook. She tried a couple of times to make dinner, but it never went over well. So, whatever grocery money she had went towards eating out. She typically went alone, while the others would hang out together. She still hadn't quite gotten on good terms with everyone yet. Besides, they were all wrapped up in the drama of Eric and Donna moving to Madison in a week. Plus, Kelso was trying to help Jackie and Hyde get back together, and Fez was sort of cheerleading that effort.

Still, Fez would go out with her a couple of times, insisting it was what husbands and wives do, and he felt it would be good to keep up appearances around town. Laurie had to admit it wasn't so bad. They'd go to the pizza place or Fatso Burger or the Hub and enjoy hanging out. He actually wasn't bad company. He was always ready with a compliment about how hot he found her, and sure, he was a perv, but something about how upfront about it he was spoke to her constant horniness. She wasn't sure whether or not it was because he was appealing or if she was just having a dry spell, but either way, she felt closer to him. Still, she wasn't ready to go all out and give an actual relationship a shot. Something didn't feel right about that. At least right now.

Right now, she was enjoying a nice round of cheesy french fries with a double bacon cheeseburger and a chocolate shake on her own. She had to admit, it really hit the spot. After all her chores and dealing with crap around the house, she was enjoying some "me time". She enjoyed her corner booth and ate to her heart's content. She hadn't enjoyed such greasy bliss in years. All that pressure to stay hot for horny guys had gotten to her, and now she was ready for some real food.

Still, the effects were beginning to catch up with her. She felt her favorite jeans getting tighter, and she couldn't deny it could just be her lousy laundry skills making them shrink. There was something wrong here. She dared a peek down at her midsection and noticed how different it looked. Gone was the toned washboard stomach that guys drank liquor off of in college. Now her stomach was a wall of flab. It peeked out over the waistband of her pants. It jiggled when she walked.

She finished the meal and ducked into the empty ladies room to lift her shirt up. It was a gut, all right. She was growing a gut. A solid week of junk food was taking its toll on her. She could only sigh pathetically. "This is what married life does to a woman," she said sadly, not sure what to do. She slapped it disparagingly, and that dislodged a great big bubble of gas that translated into a belch that echoed around the room. She went beet red, and then she realized she was hungry again. Feeling sad about the whole situation, she decided to cheer herself up with a second milkshake. She ordered it and made her way home.

133111211.content:
The final week went by, and soon, it was time for Eric and Donna to make tracks for college. Their final day coincided with Eric's 18th birthday, and the day started with a hungover Eric found on the kitchen table wearing a dress. Once that had been cleared off, Laurie looked around the kitchen and couldn't help but notice one curious thing that was rather strange in the Forman household. Today was a birthday, and there was no sign of anything party-related. Normally, when one of them had a birthday, they could expect Kitty to throw some overly-extravagant shindig. There was nothing. Not even a cake.

Given her recent fluctuation in weight, she probably should've been more appreciative of this, but she couldn't help but be a bit disappointed by the lake of baked goods. She saw her mom making a regular breakfast and chatting with Red. "Sooooo...," she drawled as she strolled over. "What're we doing for little brother's eighteenth birthday?"

Kitty looked up in surprise. "Oh my god, I didn't make his birthday breakfast!"

"Why not? You never forget."

"Well, between work and resuming intercourse with your father, I just didn't think -- "

Laurie immediately put her fingers in her ears. "Ohmygawd, why?" she moaned. "Nobody wants to hear about either of you... doing that."

"Agreed," Red said distastefully. "Kitty, I just had a heart attack."

"But the doctor gave us the go ahead. It's safe now. Tonight's my only night off."

"Ugh, imagine having to schedule sex," Laurie sighed. Then she noticed the peculiar looks her parents were sending her, so she quickly changed the subject. "So, anyway, Eric's birthday...?"

Kitty nodded and quickly pulled out a fifty dollar bill. "Here. Take this to the supermarket later today. Pick up a cake and have them right 'Happy Birthday, Eric' on it, okay?"

Laurie shrugged. "Sure." She was pretty sure a cake didn't cost all of fifty bucks, so she'd find something to do with the change.

Eric and Donna spent most of their time with the gang in the basement, celebrating his birthday and the fact that they were going away to college, filled with goodbyes and reminiscences, so she took it as a chance to sneak away and get the cake before Eric realized that Kitty had forgotten his birthday. She went to the nearest Piggly Wiggly and went to the bakery. Finding a decent vanilla cake that was big enough for the whole gang, she put in the request and gave them Eric's name. While she was there, she also picked up a carton of ice cream with chocolate syrup. Hopefully, everyone would approve of that.

She took everything through the checkout lane, and as per usual, unbuttoned her top a little to flash some cleavage to the horny teenage boy at the register, ensuring her his employee discount, enabling her to grab a couple of Snickers bars from the candy stand. She took everything to the car, drove home and sighed with relief to have it all over with. Checking the coast was clear, she grabbed everything and headed into the kitchen where Kitty was waiting.

"Oh, good, you got a big one," she said. "The kids will love that! Oh, and ice cream too! Good thinking! Where's my change?"

Laurie rolled her eyes and passed the remaining money that technically should've been more, but whatever, a few extra treats for herself weren't that big of a deal.

Kitty promptly got out a couple of candles in the shapes of a 1 and an 8 and got some matches out - which was pointless because all the kids had their own lighters - and motioned for Laurie to get the door to the basement so she could go down and surprise everyone. She listened to the cheers of delight at having cake from downstairs and couldn't help but be a bit envious. Those losers were going to eat cake without leaving any for her. She noticed the ice cream and contemplated taking that just for herself when Kitty came bounding back upstairs and snatched it.

"Laurie, help me out and bring down some plates, forks, spoons... Maybe the ice cream scooper as well..."

She watched her frenzied mother disappear back into the basement. Rolling her eyes, she grabbed six plates, six forks and the ice cream scooper in her hands and made her way down into the basement where Kitty was already lighting the candles. She sang the 'Happy Birthday' song by herself as the others agreed it was a dumb song, and Eric blew out the candles, prompting his mother to clap happily.

"Okay, here comes Laurie with plates and ice cream. Please use the utensils. I'll leave you kids to it." And with that, she hurried back upstairs.

"Here you go, kids," Laurie deadpanned, setting everything down next to the cake. "Have at it."

"Gee, thanks, sis," Eric replied.

She turned to leave, but Fez grabbed her hand. "Come on, my wife - stay and have cake."

Laurie looked startled, and she could see the apprehension in everyone else's eyes. "I don't know think..."

"Come on. It's cake! The love of cake crosses all social chasms!"

"He's got a point," Kelso said, already cutting himself a corner piece. "If all nations had access to cake, I bet there'd be no war."

"Sure there would, man," Hyde retorted, scooping himself some ice cream. "There'd be an international incident over whether chocolate or vanilla frosting is better."

"Which is a dumb argument anyway," Donna said as she proceeded to cut herself a slice. "Seeing as the best frosting ever is butterscotch."

Eric made a face. "Butterscotch? Why do I want to live with you again?" he asked playfully. She responded by kissing him, and when she pulled back, "Oh, now I remember!"

With the mood turning cheery again, Fez went to cut two slices - one for him and one for Laurie - and he joined her on the deep freeze in the corner. "Here you are, my lovely."

Laurie couldn't help but smile a bit. "Thanks," she said, taking a fork and taking a bite. She'd chosen well. This cake was bitching.

Discussions continued from cake to music to Star Wars to conspiracy theories to feminism to whatever Kelso had glued himself to recently. The hours wore on, and after a while, the cake was pretty much forgotten about as everyone began to grow sad about Eric and Donna leaving. All their stuff was packed in the Vista Cruiser, waiting to be transported to their new home in Madison. Everyone was getting a bit tipsy, save for the couple themselves as they were driving, so they indulged in one last Circle together. Even Laurie got to sit in and have a few smokes before it was inevitably time for them to leave.

They went up to the car, knowing that this was it. Laurie decided to say her goodbyes first so they could all have their own later. She knew Eric was closer to them than to her, so she felt it was only right to get out of their way. She patted them both on the shoulder and smiled, somewhat tipsy. "Well, little brother. Good luck... And don't make the same mistakes I made in college."

"Like flunking out?" Eric quipped.

"Yeah, don't do that. Not good. Trust me." She indulged in hugging him for a moment, and after he got over the surprise, he hugged back. "See you at Thanksgiving," she muttered before turning and walking back towards the basement. Before she opened the door, she looked back at the group of friends as they hugged and got emotional, and then saw Red and Kitty walk outside and join in the goodbyes. Sighing wistfully, she stumbled down to the basement again.

The remnants of the party were all there. The cake was half finished, as was the ice cream. And then Laurie got the biggest case of the munchies ever. It all looked so good, and she was starving...

She quickly gathered up a fork, the cake and the ice cream and smuggled it all up the stairs until she was safely in her room. With a crazed look in her eye, Laurie began to chow down. Half a large birthday cake and half a tub of half-melted ice cream - it was no mean feat. She felt so ravenous - that damn circle! But she didn't care right now. She just started shoveling everything down. Gorging and slurping and enjoying every last bite - she barely stopped to taste any of it. She just had to inhale all of it. Her stomach stretched and seemed to balloon right in front of her, and by the time she was done, she must've looked almost three months pregnant.

With a hiccup, she gathered the empty containers together before noticing her jeans were straining. Knowing what to do, she changed into some flannel pajamas and headed outside. Goodbyes were just wrapping up as she put the trash on the counter to be taken away later. She saw everyone waving goodbye to Eric and Donna as the Vista Cruiser pulled out. Relieved for the distraction, she waddled awkwardly back to her bedroom and laid back in bed. She patted her stomach, which seemed to be finally satisfied. With another hiccup, she took a deep breath and went to sleep.

Soon, everyone was getting into a new routine. Red had been hoping that, with Eric moved out at long last, that everyone would finally stop hanging out at his house. No such luck. Since Hyde still lived in the basement, he became the one that everyone came to visit. Jackie, of course, because they were dating, but Kelso and Fez kept coming over as well, much to Red's annoyance.

Kitty didn't mind, though. In fact, she found it greatly fulfilling that her house had become the "hang out" house on the block. It helped keep her mind off Eric. That, combined with her extra shifts at the hospital, helped keep her relatively sane.

Laurie, meanwhile, was sticking to her end of the bargain. For better or for worse, she was doing as many chores around the house as she could. Hyde helped occasionally, too, like mowing the lawn, but most of the time, he just hung out in the basement with his loser friends. She was stuck with dishes, laundry, cleaning and cooking. Just further proof that there was no god. Someone as hot as her shouldn't have to put up with this crap. She wished Red would hire a maid.

Still, cooking wasn't the worst thing in the world. Kitty gave her a weekly allowance for grocery shopping, and she gave her a list of all the things Red wasn't allowed to eat while he was recovering from his heart attack. However, her mother was so frazzled from working so much that she rarely, if ever, asked for change. Laurie was quick to take advantage of this. At first, she just used it to buy beer, but lately, she found herself gravitating towards snacks as well. Mostly of the sugary or salty variety - chips, crackers, soda, doughnuts, ding-dongs, twinkies, and various other processed confectioneries worked their way into her daily diet. She hid boxes of them in her room so her dad wouldn't be tempted, and she'd snack on them between chores.

As the days wore on, she ended up just wearing sweats or pajama pants all day. She rarely had time to go out and get her usual fill of sex, so she didn't try as hard to look sexy every day. Her hair was a bit frizzier, her clothes were baggy, and she only put on the minimum amount of makeup. She wasn't an animal, after all.

Of course, it didn't help when Jackie came over all perky and peppy to see the gang, and she would wear the latest fashion and how good it looked on her. Laurie tended to make herself scarce on those occasions. She felt like she wasn't the prettiest girl in the room anymore whenever she was around. God, why couldn't the guys make friends with some fat girls? That'd really cheer her up.

Laurie glanced at herself in the mirror one morning. She had a definitely potbelly in development. Probably from all the pot. Munchies were a common factor. Too many times, she'd woken up to find she'd finished off her snacks in the night during a circle-induced feeding frenzy. She usually had enough cash to get more, but it was still a pain in the ass.

One evening, she'd finally finished all the chores required of her. Red was in the garage during some repair work and Kitty was at work, so she had the night to herself. She slumped back on the couch and watched some old "I Love Lucy" reruns.

The door from the kitchen swung open, and in walked Fez, looking a bit frazzled. Laurie was tempted to not give him the time of day, but the look of shock on his face was hard to ignore.

"Do I even want to know?" she sneered.

"She's pregnant...," Fez said in a flat voice, still looking very distant.

Laurie scoffed. "I highly doubt you have the power to perform that deed," she muttered.

Fez came out of his trance thanks to the burn and glared at her. "No, not me. Kelso! He got Brooke pregnant!"

"Oh... That'd be more shocking if I had half a clue who Brooke was."

"She was valedictorian at our high school a couple years ago. They had sex in a restroom. Badda-boom-badda-bing. Pregnant!"

Laurie shook her head. "Sounds like an amateur to me. An old pro like me knows how to avoid the ol' 'knock-knock-knock' on the uterus."

Fez let a pervy grin slide across his face. "I bet you do."

Laurie rolled her eyes, but a small smirk played across her lips as he clearly thought he was being sexy.

Much to her annoyance, he decided to sit down on the couch next to her and put his feet on the coffee table she'd cleaned earlier. "I tell ya... Eric and Donna are off at college, Jackie and Hyde are back together, Kelso knocked a girl up, and you and I are married. We've all grown up so much."

"We're married so you can stay in the country. As soon as you get citizenship, we're divorced. Comprende?"

Fez's smile wilted. "Comprendo."

"Good. Now then, be a good husband and fetch me a beer."

"Okay, but can we not say 'fetch'? Sounds vaguely like I'm being compared to a dog."

"Whatever."

Fez got up and left. Then, true to his word, he returned with a beer. She took it without saying thank you, cracking it open and taking a swig. She quietly waited for him to leave, but he sat down next to her again, causing her to silently throw her head back in annoyance.

"Ooooh, Lucy!" he said eagerly. "I love this show!"

"Yeah? They got it in your country?" she asked, only vaguely interested.

"No, but I watched it a lot when I first came to America. It was one of the shows I learned English from. That and the Price is Right."

"That explains a few things," Laurie nodded.

"Yes, America is a wonderful country. Where else can you win a free car for knowing the capitol of Rhode Island?"

She smirked a bit. He was funnier when he wasn't trying to be funny. She had to admit, of all the guys in the group she could've married, he was a pretty good one. He wasn't a thinker like Hyde, but he wasn't clueless like Kelso. Plus, he wasn't her brother like Eric, which was an infinite plus.

"Do you want anymore snacks, my lovely wife?" he asked.

Her eyebrows rose in surprise. "Sure. Surprise me."

"Right away!" He rose off the couch and headed back to the kitchen.

Laurie couldn't help the small smile on her lips. Not a smirk, but an actual smile. He was pretty sweet.

But then she shook those thoughts out of her head. Ew. No. This was Fez. Bad thoughts.

He reentered with an armful of snack cakes and chips. "Any of these?" he asked.

The smile came back.
1331112112.title: She doesn't worry about her weight and goes...

Red thinks Laurie is wasting her potential
13311121121.content:
So it began.

Over the next two weeks, Fez was constantly bring his green card wife snacks. While she worked on dishes, cleaning and laundry, Fez kept bringing her food. Sometimes, it'd just be snack cakes and chips that were already in the house, but other times, he'd go for takeout, bringing her burgers, fries, chinese, pizza and soda. She'd be sitting on the couch, waiting for the laundry to finish, and he'd walk through the door with bags of greasy goodness for her. She was in hog's heaven.

Of course, it all started to catch up with her. She wore sweats most of the time, so it wasn't noticeable at first, but one day, when she decided to put on a pair of jeans, she found they wouldn't button up. The button couldn't reach the hole. She struggled quite a bit to make it work, but it just wouldn't connect. She rolled around on the bed, grunting and squealing as she tried to make the stubborn clasp hold, but it was no good. These jeans just would not close.

It was in the middle of all this racket that her husband entered with another round of goodies. "I could hear you from outside, Laurie," he announced. "Have you started without me?"

Laurie glared at him. "I always start without you," she sneered.

Fez looked momentarily hurt, but then he shrugged. "I guess that's fair. God knows I've started without you plenty of times."

Laurie finally stopped struggling and flopped on her bed, utterly spent. She peered up at Fez, only to have her vision mostly blocked by the growing mound that was her belly.

"Fez, am I getting fat?" she asked fearfully.

"No, of course not, my lovely," he said pleasantly.

"You're not just saying that?"

"Of course not."

"Cuz I feel like you kind of are."

Fez considered. "Well, I have been told that the correct answer to that question is always 'no', so I always make a point to say it when asked."

Laurie nodded understandingly. "Yeah, but... if you weren't just saying the 'correct' answer and were in fact saying what you thought... am I getting fat?"

Fez winced. "Well... I mean, I..."

"Fez, you've got nothing to lose. It's not like I can withhold sex from you, seeing as how we're not sleeping together."

"That's sadly true... Okay, I'll tell you the truth."

"Thank you."

"... I think the dryer shrunk most of your clothes."

"... Huh?"

"You just haven't noticed because you've been wearing your wide variety of stylish sexy sweats these last few weeks. Perhaps you are not doing well with laundry."

"You think? But... Dad and Hyde's clothes go through my laundry, too, and they haven't complained."

"Well, maybe... maybe women's clothes are more sensitive than men's...?"

Laurie raised an eyebrow. "Right...," she drawled. "Are you lying to me again?"

"... No?"

"Ugh. Fez!"

"I'm sorry, my lovely, but I can't bring myself to say a bad word against you! You shouldn't feel bad about yourself! I mean, at least, not anymore... You are doing a good thing by taking care of your family so Eric can go to college. You are helping people who love you, and you should feel proud of yourself. You even became betrothed to me, even though I mean nothing to you, just to keep me in the country. So I don't want you to feel bad because you may or may not have gained weight recently. Which you haven't, by the way!"

Laurie stared at him with a wide-eyed expression. She felt... moved. This idiot was a total loser, nothing to offer, but he had such a way with words. For the briefest of moments, she felt her withered almost-dead heart flutter. It wasn't much, but it was something.

She looked down at her round orb of a belly, placing a hand on it thoughtfully. She couldn't help but take a degree of pride in it. It was a symbol of her sacrifice. Of the first truly selfless thing she'd done in her whole worthless life. She looked at it with a newfound sense of appreciation.

Then, she looked up at Fez, who was looking at her with that increasingly-attractive sense of husbandly duty and concern, and she saw the mountain of greasy takeout and a box of doughnuts beckoning to her, reminding her of how hungry she was.

"... You're right, Fez."

"I am? About what?"

"These pants shrunk in the wash. No big deal. Come on. I'll change into some sweats, and then we can have dinner."

"Oooh, yay! Wear the black ones! They compliment the curve of your sensual hips!"

"Oh, I know they do," she said with a wink, and she disappeared into the closet.

Kelso comes in moaning about his looming parenthood
133111211211.content:
"What do you mean Tonto has to live here?!" Red practically exploded. "If the government wants to come ship him off to wherever the hell he came from, then it's our god-given right as Americans to lead them to him!"

"Oh, Red, stop that!" Kitty chided. "Eric would never forgive you if you sent one of his closest friends to... wherever this young man is from!"

"I don't care! I've had enough of having to deal with the fact that Laurie married Tarzan here just so he could stay in the country! I want him out of my house and out of my family!"

"Daddy!" Laurie snapped, looking him dead in the eye. "Look, I'm sorry if me helping Fez isn't 'American' enough for you! But I did it, and here we are! And enough with the racist nicknames! His name is... really hard to pronounce, but he goes by 'Fez'!"

"Yeah, and Tarzan was white, dammit!" Fez added.

Hyde, who'd been pretty quiet up until now, decided that it was time for him to say something. After all, if Laurie of all people could stand up for Fez, so could he. "Look, Red, I get that this is getting your star-spangled banner in a bunch, but you have to consider the consequences of not going along with this unholy union."

"Such as what?" Red demanded.

"Well, it's not just Fez that gets in trouble if they find out the marriage is a sham. If they find out she contributed to an illegal living in America, Laurie could go to jail, too."

"She could?"

"I could?!"

"Yep. In fact, we all might go to jail just for harboring him."

Everyone in the room looked at each other as the weight of the burnout's words weighed heavily on them.

"... Okay...," Red sighed at last. "If it protects the family, what do I need to do?"

"Well, Red," Kitty said awkwardly. "It might be nice if you just let me do all the talking. Saying nice things about Fez has never been your strong suit."

"Agreed. So I'll probably just smile and nod."

"Oh, don't strain yourself, sweetie. Just settle for nodding."

They left the kitchen to start making plans, leaving Laurie standing with her "husband" and "brother".

"Thank you, Hyde," Fez said gratefully. "I look forward to being a fake Forman like you."

"Anytime, little buddy," Hyde replied, clapping on the shoulder - the closest he could ever bring himself to a hug. "I always embrace an opportunity to screw with the government. The fact that it helps someone is just a coincidence."

"Now we just have to create the facade that this is a normal healthy loving marriage," Laurie sighed, leaning against the table.

"Does that mean we get to share a bed?" Fez asked eagerly.

Laurie rolled her eyes. "I think my dad might kill you. Eric's room is just gathering dust, though."

"It would be if your mom wasn't constantly cleaning it," Hyde smirked. "She keeps dusting and vacuuming on the off chance he comes home and turns five again."

"Poor Miss Kitty. I should do something nice for her," Fez mused.

"Mowing the lawn seems like a good place to start," Laurie replied. "Just don't run over her garden again."

"Very well. And when I return, I think I'll make lunch for you, my wife."

"Good boy," she said, patting him on his head. "Run along. And don't let the mean old lawnmower scare you this time."

"Ai, that was one time!"

He turned and strode out towards the garage, leaving Laurie to start making herself some breakfast. Thankfully, in the past few weeks, she'd gotten rather good at making her own waffles and pancakes. Rather than waste time trying to decide on which one to make, she decided to split the difference and make both.

Hyde was pouring himself some corn flakes, absently reaching for the milk when she poured it into the pancake mix she was preparing. He glared from behind his shades, but she wordlessly returned it a moment later. As he poured it on his cereal, he quietly observed her at work behind the counter. She didn't have the look of someone horribly depressed. Well, she did, given the sweats, the messy hair, lack of makeup and muffin top, but she still seemed happy enough. Usually, her happiness was laced with a smug superiority. But this was different. She seemed less smug and more... relaxed. It wasn't something he was used to. Normally, if they weren't ignoring each other, they were bombarding each other with insults.

Unable to deal with the silence anymore, he cleared his throat and took a chance on speaking. "So... settled into marital bliss pretty well, have you?"

She looked up at him with a hint of the usual derision she usually reserved for him and his friends. "Yep. Knowing Jackie, you'll probably be dragged kicking and screaming down the aisle sometime in the next few months."

Hyde smirked. They hadn't lost their insults. Thank god.

"Yeah, well... just glad to see you're actually doing right by your husband. Which means, roughly, you're trying to keep him from being deported. I'm sure you're still entertaining all the guys in town."

Laurie raised an eyebrow. "Meh... not really up for it right now. I mean, I could, I suppose, but there's so much laundry and cleaning and cooking I have to do now to help out... I dunno..."

Hyde took his shades off in surprise. "The legendary Laurie Forman has lost interest in sex?" he asked, putting a hand to his chest in fake shock.

"Pft! As if! I just... I don't know... When Dad had his heart attack, and because of something I did... It just kind of... put everything in perspective, y'know? Like... maybe there's more to life than partying, boozing and... sexing, I think?"

"Taking responsibility and being useful...," Hyde mused, tapping his shades against the table. "Can't argue with that. Unless they expect me to do it, too."

Laurie smirked. "Well, you've toasted so many brain cells, you probably can't even sort the mail anymore."

"I'd take a stand and prove you wrong if I gave a rat's ass."

Laurie cooked diligently through their conversation - waffles on the left, pancakes on the right - and was pleased to find they were about done. She got down a large plate and started to pile them up on it.

"If that's lunch, I give you points for laziness," Hyde remarked.

"Please, this is breakfast. Someone's got to cook it."

"Does that mean you're sharing?"

Laurie glared sternly. "Make your own, deadbeat."

"All that, just for you? Man, you're really not interested in sex with random strangers."

"Hey! I'll have you know I could still get any guy I wanted! I'm just... taking a sabbatical!"

"Or you're - dare I say it - settling down."

"Bite your tongue!"

"Hey, you seem to be fitting into the 'housewife' status pretty comfortably."

"I'm just helping out. I have other things I want to do, you know!"

"Such as...?"

"Well... I... didn't think you'd ask me that so soon..."

Hyde smirked again. "Look, I'm not gonna tell you what to do..."

"Damn right, you're not."

"...because I think you're doing the right thing."

"... oh... huh?"

"You're helping your parents, you're helping Fez... Who would've thought big bad Laurie Forman would have heart after all?"

"Oh, go to hell!" she snapped, stuffing a forkful of waffles / pancakes in her mouth to smother a smile from forming.

Hyde chuckled and got up. "Okay, gotta go. Jackie wants a ride to the mall."

"May god have mercy on your lack of soul."

"Yeah, like you're one to talk."

He grabbed the keys to the Camino and walked out via the patio door.

Laurie continued to stuff her face, devouring the large stack of food in front of her. Within ten minutes, it was all gone, butter, syrup and all. She leaned back in her chair and enjoyed the resulting fullness in her gut.

She peered down. Her gut. Her great big gut. It bulged with the enormity of her gorge. She patted it soothingly. Kinda nice, actually. To actually enjoy fattening food was kinda nice. To just kind of kick back and let herself go was also kinda nice.
133111211211.title: Fez moves in

choices: Red starts pressuring Fez and Laurie to divorce
Laurie starts to really enjoy eating
1331112112111.content:
It was another two days before the government agent came a-knockin' at their door. He had the look of your typical federal agent - icky, boring and kind of reptilian. He strode through the door with the stereotypical dark suit and briefcase, as if that was all they had to wear in the FBI. Laurie couldn't help but frown at the suit. Didn't they know that by trying to look inconspicuous, they were only making themselves look more inconspicuous? Everything about him screamed "FBI" and "official government doofus" and "not gettin' any".

Still, he was the man who would ultimately decide Fez's fate, whether they approved of his dress code or not. They welcomed him in, made him comfortable on the couch, and smiled politely as he droned on about nothing. He said he wanted to interview everyone separately. They were all silently thankful that Hyde was at work right now, so he wouldn't be expected to give a statement or anything. While they knew he'd probably want to help Fez, that wouldn't be enough to stop him from insulting the government, probably landing him in worse trouble than Fez was.

So they all were interviewed. Her and Fez first, and her parents second.

Their interview went somewhat fine. Fez seemed a little too eager to brag about how he bagged her quicker than you can say "corn on the cob" for some reason. The guy had been a virgin for so long that he simply felt the need to boast about his "experience" whenever he could, even if it meant deportation. Still, his tone assured her that the agent guy probably wouldn't suspect him of lying. Sadly.

Still, they kept up the little backstory that they'd cooked up. Hyde had advised them that the best way to lie was to sprinkle it with bits of truth. So, they kept it simple. Fez was a friend of her brother's, and they'd known each other for a while before things got serious - true. They had sex for the first time during a camping trip - true.

And that was the most truth they could come up with.

They'd managed to weasel their way around the truth with the semi-plausible storyline that they'd dated for two years, and Fez had proposed earlier that year, with the intention that they'd get married in winter or something, but when his visa unexpectedly expired, they decided to move the date up to keep him in the country and to "protect our love".

The agent had nodded, but he also raised an eyebrow. Laurie suspected he was suspicious.

So they were later hustled out of the living room to the kitchen, and her parents were called in to replace them. They let out a breath they hadn't known they'd been holding and relaxed against the counter.

"Aiiiii," Fez moaned. "So many questions, so few lies..."

"Tell me about it," Laurie huffed. "I swear, the tension is driving me crazy."

"Hmmmmm... if only there was some way to relieve the tension in a... conjoined manner..."

She stared unimpressed as he waggled his eyebrows suggestively. It was so pathetic it was almost cute.

"Okay, no," she said. "We're not having sex while we're being questioned by the government."

"Why not? They're trying to find out if we really love each other! What better way than by finally consummating this puppy?"

"Because I don't want to. At least, not right this second, okay? I just... I just don't want to..."

Fez tilted his head quizzically. "Why not? Usually, you're an 'any-port-in-a-storm' type of girl." She gave him a look. "No offense," he added quickly.

Laurie slumped over to the fridge. "I don't know... This whole situation has been to stressful for sex. I just... I dunno... I mean, I still feel urges, but now I feel guilty for having them. Like, how can I think about sex when my dad almost died and I might get sent to jail for marrying you?" She pulled out some leftover fried chicken from last night and starting eating again.

Fez gently put a hand on her shoulder. "I am sorry, my lovely. I am letting my loins be my brains. An act that has gotten me in more trouble than I can count. I should be more receptive to your needs. You are going through a lot right now, and I must respect that."

She smiled gratefully. "Thanks, Fez. I appreciate it."

Fez smiled back. "Even with a mouthful of KFC, you are still the vision of an angel."

Okay, now she was getting that weird fluttery feeling she got when he complimented her. She had to admit, it was a step up from "nice boobs".

Eventually, the interviews ended, and although there was a brief moment of uncertainty where it looked like Red was finally going to say exactly what he thought of their union, he ultimately agreed to keep up the ruse and described them as a couple that was "very much in love", something that was clearly not easy for him. Thankfully, he got through it without another heart attack, and it seemed to be enough for the agent. It would take some time, but Fez would be able to become a citizen in the coming weeks.

After he said goodbye and left, Laurie hugged Red and thanked him for his help. He smiled grudgingly before shoving Fez away before he could hug him as well. Kitty was so happy that no one was going to jail that she announced she'd be making a big dinner for everyone, which perked Laurie right up.

While they waited for dinner, Laurie popped upstairs and saw Fez was moving his things out of Eric's room. "Where are you going?" she asked.

"I am going back to live with my host parents," he explained. "I am grateful to your family for putting up with me these last few days, but I mustn't burden you all much longer. Otherwise, Red will kill me while I sleep. Or I will kill him when he's awake with another heart attack. Might be best if we just avoid each other for awhile."

Laurie couldn't help but pout a little bit. "Oh... okay, that makes sense, I guess... But you'll still visit all the time, right?"

"Of course!" he smiled. "Hyde still lives in the basement. As long as I'm down there, I should be all right."

"Hyde... right...," she murmured.

"And of course," he continued, "should you ever want to engage in marital bliss at any point in the future, you only have to call." He waggled his eyebrows again. Okay, dammit, that shouldn't be cute. But it was.

She let a small smile spread across her lips. "I might take you up on that sometime."

Happily, dinner time rolled around not long after, and they went downstairs to join everyone at the table. As per usual, Kitty had gone overboard with cooking, as she often did when she was either happy or depressed. Chicken, ham, mashed potatoes, sweet potatoes, peas, string beans, steamed carrots, devilled eggs... Simply too much to count.

Everyone was there, of course. As soon as they knew Mrs. Forman was cooking, they all sat around in eager anticipation. Hyde with Jackie, of course, but Kelso had joined in as well, seeing as how he was feeling depressed about Brooke not wanting him to be a part of their child's life. Fez felt that, for his own sake, he'd better not sit next to Laurie as long as Red was watching. She was a little sad about that, but she also didn't want him to die, so she didn't make a fuss.

Dinner went pleasantly and somewhat uneventfully. Since the drama concerning the government was resolved, talk turned to Kelso's impending fatherhood and his sadness that Brooke had turned him away. Of course, everyone had an opinion on that. Kitty told him he should persist while Red told him to back off. Jackie told him to buy her something expensive while Hyde said to give her space for now. Fez suggested "doing it", of course.

Laurie threw in every once in a while, but right now, she was starving. The relief of not getting in trouble with the government was such a relief, and now she was ravenous. It was like she just couldn't have enough. As the conversation continued around her, she took advantage of the distraction to sneak extra portions onto her plate. She piled it high, poured extra gravy and butter on pretty much everything and tucked in. She ate with a desire that she normally reserved for intercourse. It felt so good to finally be eating what she wanted when she wanted.

The dinner went on for an hour, with the discussion going from Kelso's problem to the latest letter from Eric and Donna to Hyde's job at the restaurant to Red's next doctor appointment. Soon, however, everyone was tired and full, so one by one, they all got up to go and clean up. Hyde, Jackie, Kelso and Fez all politely thanked Mrs. Forman for dinner, which made her so happy she let out her trademark laugh before shooing them all away. Red slouched off to his chair to watch some TV while the gang made their to the basement and Kitty started doing dishes.

Laurie opted to go up to her room for a bit. God, she was stuffed. She must've eaten three quarters of all that food herself. Her sweats had allowed her to let loose her appetite in a way regular pants just wouldn't cut. She could feel the beginning of a waddle happening between her thighs as they began to brush together. When she got to her room, she slipped off her top and looked herself up and down. What a belly she had going on. Look at the way it bulged out like a balloon. She gave it a slap and let out a whimper - gawd, that had hurt! She was so painfully overstuffed that moving was extremely difficult.

Moaning to herself, she laid out flat on her back on her bed. She was exhausted. What a long day.

But, she had to admit, it had been a good day. They'd gotten through everything, survived, and had a good night together.

And a good meal together, she reminded herself, rubbing her belly soothingly. She hoped there would be more such meals in the future. She didn't know why, but somehow, stuffing her belly into a globe was extremely pleasurable. Full of bliss and food, she fell into a lovely food coma.

13311121121111.content:
And now, the universe was going to go back to being unfair as Bob showed up at the Formans morbidly depressed because Joanne had broken up with him for... reasons. So now he was hanging around the house all the time. He'd been lonely enough without Donna, so now he had that whole house to himself. Kitty, of course, was always eager to help him out, but Red, of course, was constantly annoyed by his presence.

It got really bad when she came down into the basement to hang out one day, only to find Bob already there, hanging out with Jackie and Kelso, watching the tube. She rolled her eyes in dismay as she slumped down into the empty garden chair. It was technically Fez's chair, but what the hell - they were married, weren't they? She sat her slightly heavier-than-usual ass on it and took out a nail file, doing a little work while she was there.

"Hey, Bob," she said in her usual disinterested way.

"Hey, kiddo," he replied pleasantly.

They all sat in silence for a long time, none of them really sure what to say or do.

Finally, Kelso took a chance and tried talking. "Bob...? What're you doing here?"

Bob shrugged. "I just thought I'd try it out."

"How's it going?"

"... A little uncomfortable. I thought it'd be better than sitting home alone." He shook his head. "It's not."

With that, he finally got up and left, allowing everyone to slump with relief.

"Oh my GAWD, the guy is hopeless," Jackie sighed. "It's like he doesn't know what to do with himself after a break up. Why can't he just go to the mall and max out his dad's credit cards like everyone else?"

"Why'd he and Joanne break up, anyway?" Laurie asked. "I thought they were solid."

"No idea," Kelso replied, lying out on the couch. "Don't think he's all that sure himself."

"Well, once when I was sad, when Michael was cheating on me I got flowers from a secret admirer, and it cheered me right up.
I mean, sure I sent them to myself. But it's the thought that counts."

"You sent them? You let me go on about how I sent them to you!"

"I know. I was enjoying watching you squirm," Jackie said with a smile.

"Ooooh, I like that!" Laurie said approvingly. "You go, girl!"

The two girls laughed together, making Kelso pout. "Dammit, it's bad enough Fez is trying to take the waiter job at the hotel from me!"

"Fez is what?" Laurie asked.

"Hyde put him onto that waiter job I've been trying to get. I mean, I've got a baby on the way! I need to prove to Brooke that I'm responsible!"

"Yeah, well, my husband is trying to get a job so he's not some deadbeat loser. I mean, it's only a matter of time before his host parents find out he's not in high school anymore. Having a job will help him when they throw him out. Plus, it'll help him get his green card."

"Pft! You guys are gonna divorce anyway! What's the big deal?"

Laurie glared at him. "Look, I put a lot of work into helping him stay in the country. I'm not going to let it get screwed up just cuz you knocked some poor girl up, okay? Besides, it'd be nice if he helped my family out. Dad can't work, so every little bit helps. Once the booze runs out, they might try to drink us."

"But you don't have to stay married for that," Jackie pointed out. "I mean, his green card's on the way. It should be safe to start dumping his ass by now."

Laurie fidgeted. "I'll get around to it... Just, y'know... better safe than sorry."

Jackie narrowed her eyes suspiciously at her, like she knew something was up, but she didn't say anything for the time being. The midget was showing restraint for a change, Laurie thought. Damn, this maturity thing was spreading like wildfire.

Of course, while some were willing to let Laurie's decisions go, Red was less than pleased. He'd done his part now that the INS agent had been and gone. Now it was just a matter of getting them divorced. He'd sent Laurie to the courthouse with fifty dollars to get the proceedings started, but she'd ended up spending it on a compact mirror, some makeup and a big lunch from Fatso Burger.

Fez and Laurie weren't exactly causing much trouble around the house. Since she'd lost the will to whore herself out all the time, and he'd moved back out again, you'd hardly guess they were married. Although, every time he showed up at the house, she'd make a point of greeting him and asking how he was, and sometimes, she'd hang out in the basement with him and the gang. Since she'd been a big help earlier, they had to admit they were warming up to her. And she'd usually see him off when he was leaving.

Red was in two minds about it. In a way, he felt like he should be glad that she seemed to be finally settling down, but did it have to be with one of Eric's idiot friends? There wasn't anything about Fez he disliked in particular - other than him being foreign - but he didn't like the way they'd gotten married on the spur of the moment. A green card marriage was just so... blech.

So, one day, he'd had enough, and he decided he was going to take them down to the courthouse and get them a divorce whether they liked it or not. They both looked very hangdog about it, but he'd made his decision. However, when they opened the door to leave, they found a box on the welcome mat. It was a wedding present.

Kitty admitted she'd told people about it. "Well, I had to tell a few people because I never thought I'd be able to say 'Laurie got married' without adding 'and the baby came early'."

Although Red was insistent that they return the gift, Kitty, Laurie and Fez still enthusiastically unwrapped it when they realized it was a new microwave, something Kitty had been wanting for a long time. So they spent the night playing with the microwave, making everything from popcorn to a baked potato - and of course, Laurie ate everything that came out.

The next day, Red was still trying to get them to have their divorce, and he wasn't happy when he saw the microwave had been used. But then, yet another gift came, and this time it was a power saw.

"It's from Billy Schneider down at the hardware store," Laurie explained. "He's had a crush on me since I went ladder shopping in that miniskirt."

Fez got very serious. "Okay, just to make it clear. If you're buying me a gift I want candy. For my birthday, Christmas, daylight savings-- candy. Candy!"

"Okay, Fez, candy!" Laurie replied. "But remember, as your wife, I'm entitled to fifty percent."

"Agreed. Now then - you can keep the saw, Red."

Red had been admiring the power saw the entire time it had been in his hand, and he looked startled. "... No, that would be wrong...," he said, clearly torn.

"Well...," Kitty said slyly. "It would be wrong if they were divorced... But if they stayed married, sending the gifts back would be rude."

"You make a good point!"

Laurie raised a playful eyebrow. "I thought you wanted us to get divorced, Daddy."

"I'll tell you what, honey. We'll wait a month. If a riding mower hasn't shown up by then, we'll talk."

Laurie discreetly hid a small smile and patted him on the shoulder, motioning for Fez to follow her to the basement. It was time for "I Love Lucy" anyway.

"So did you get the job at the restaurant?" she asked.

"I did indeed! It seems people feel very comfortable asking a foreigner to fetch things for them."

Laurie rolled her eyes. "Yeah, well, it's something to put on a resume. And maybe we can buy Daddy a riding mower and pretend it was sent in the mail or something."

They plopped down on the couch side by side, enjoying the black and white reruns together. They must've been there for a while, because as the day wore on, they slumped together on the couch, getting incredibly close to each other, which should've felt weird, but Laurie found it quite nice to just lean up against him and let her mind go.

She was just toying with the idea of leaning over and kissing him when the door burst open, making them jump. It was Kelso, looking particularly insane with glee, while Hyde and Jackie came in behind him.

"Roy's going to give me another chance!" he yelled happily.

Laurie and Fez sat up straight in surprise. "Wait, what?!"

"Yeah, one of the waitresses quit because he wouldn't stop hitting on her, so there's an opening now! This is my second chance!"

"Oh, happy day!" Fez cried, leaping to his feet. "I felt so horrible about showing you up in front of everyone in such a humiliating manner!"

"Eh, I say let bygones be bygones," Hyde said, patting his two friends on the shoulders. "The important thing is that we get to watch Kelso fail all over again, which is something we can all celebrate."

"Yeah!" Kelso said cheerily before realizing what he'd said. "Wait a minute..."

"Don't worry, Kelso. Now that we are no longer competing, I will show you how to become a great waiter."

"And I will endeavor to be as unhelpful as humanly possible," Hyde agreed.

"Wow, thanks, guys," Kelso said, genuinely touched.

"Come on, we'll go upstairs and see if Miss Kitty has some trays and plates we can practice with," Fez said, motioning towards the stairs.

Hyde and Kelso went on ahead upstairs, but Fez took a moment to readdress Laurie, who still looked a little bewildered by all of this happening so fast. "Pardon me, my lovely, but I have a friend in need. I shall return. Possibly with many injuries. And hopefully, a pizza."

Laurie smiled. "You're good. Take your time," she said, waving him off.

But to her surprise, Fez leaned down and kissed her on the cheek before hurrying after the others.

Once he was gone, she couldn't help the goofy grin on her face. But then she remembered that Jackie was seated in the lawn chair, eyeing her carefully.

Laurie shifted awkwardly under Jackie's suspicious gaze. She was feeling really uncomfortable, which shouldn't be possible in her designer sweat pants. She curled her legs up onto the couch indian-style, trying to avoid eye contact, but the brunette midget was very good at judgemental stares. All those years on the pep squad had given her that gift. Good god, what was going through that girl's tiny-yet-single-tracked mind?

"So...," Jackie drawled, tapping the arm of the lawn chair with her perfectly-manicured index finger. "What's the deal with you and -- ?"

"Oh, look!" Laurie said, suddenly pulling a magazine out of the cushions. "Teen Beat magazine! Wanna find out what Scott Baio's favorite color is?!"

Jackie stared at the magazine in amazement. "Oh, wow! I haven't read that issue yet!" she cried, snatching it out of the older girl's hand. "How'd you even get this?! Even someone as girly as Eric wouldn't be subscribed to it?! I can't believe...!" Alas, she trailed off and saw the fake smile plastered all over Laurie's face. "Ugh...," she grunted, putting it back on the table between them. "I can't believe I almost fell for that, you brilliant bitch."

Laurie squirmed and tried her best to shrink down into the couch out of sight, but she couldn't bend that way.

"Look," Jackie said, leaning in close. "All I want to know is what's going on with you and Fez. No weaseling out of it."

"Nothing's going on! It's just... you know, green card marriage! Nothing more!"

"Oh my god, are you kidding me?!" Jackie cried.

"What?"

"'Nothing more'? Could you be anymore transparent? Any time you say it's 'nothing more', it's always 'something more'!"

Laurie squirmed again. "Look, it's none of your business, okay?"

"Hey! I'm a gossip! It's always my business! And I deserve to know if Fez is involved with a woman who's just going to rip his heart out and stomp on it for some guy in a butcher shop with nice arms!"

The two women stared at each other.

"... What?!" Laurie exclaimed.

Jackie took a breath to calm herself. "Look... Fez is one of my best friends. Okay, he's not that good-looking and he's a complete loser, but he's still a nice guy. And I don't like the idea of him getting together with you. Because, no offense, you're a whore."

"Hey!" Laurie snapped.

"I said 'no offense'!"

"Look, I've had a lot going on right now. Dad's heart attack, Eric leaving for college, the government investigating me... And you know what? Fez has been very supportive through all of this. He does things for me, brings me things, watches TV with me... He even shares his candy with me, and I have it on good authority that he never does that with anyone!"

Jackie nodded at that.

"I don't know if I'm in love with the guy, but I like him a lot. And I know I don't have the best track record with respecting peoples' feelings, but I'm working on that. And for all I know, Fez doesn't even like me that way. He might just be being polite and hoping it gets him laid."

"Whoa, waitwaitwait," Jackie interjected, holding up a hand. "You haven't had sex with him?"

"Just the once, during the camping trip... which, as it happens, was the last time I had sex."

Jackie's eyes widened. "Laurie, that was all the way back in May! It's been five months!"

"I know! I just... I can't bring myself to do it anymore! There was this guy, Carlos, who I almost went out with, but I just kept thinking of my dad in a hospital bed and I couldn't do it!"

Now she was almost certain that Jackie was looking vaguely sympathetic. It was always hard to tell with this girl.

"So...," she continued, "that's all that's going on with me and Fez. Yes, I like him. Yes, I have feelings for him. No, I'm not using him. No, I'm not going to deliberately break his heart. Okay?"

Jackie nodded slowly. "Okay...," she said with a somewhat accepting tone. "But just remember. I kicked your ass once. I can kick it again."

Laurie nodded in response. "Noted."

A bright smile split across Jackie's face and she bounced like the cheerleader she was. "Good! Glad we got that settled! Now, lemme at that Teen Beat!" She snatched up the magazine and started flipping through it. "Although, to hell with Scott Baio," she added, not looking up. "Something about him just makes me cringe..."

Laurie shrugged and peered over at the nearby deep freeze. She needed a sugar fix, pronto. She headed over and dug around past the meat until she found the goodies - popsicles, pushups... oooh, ice cream sandwiches, too! How'd she not known about those? She pulled the box out and carried it back over to the sofa. She began ripping one open and took a bite, moaning softly at the soft chocolate cookie with vanilla goodness in between.

Then, she realized that she was being stared at again. Jackie was looking up from the magazine with a raised eyebrow.

"... Want one?" she asked, holding the box up.

"... Think I'm good," the other girl replied, looking back at the magazine.

Laurie shrugged, finished the first sandwich, and then started in on the second one. It was weird that Jackie wasn't making snide comments on her weight, seeing as how mocking fat people was one of those things she delighted in. Either the cheerleader really was growing up, or she wasn't paying that much attention. It could really be either one.

She finished the second one and looked down into the box. There were still eight left. She smiled. It was going to be a good day after all.

If she could get these damn red pants to button up. She took a deep breath, sucked in her considerable gut, and felt sweet relief as the button went through the hole. She'd had to go up three sizes lately, but Fez had been more than happy to pay for some new clothes with his new paycheck.

Happily, since he'd gotten a job and was making an honest living, Red had eased up slightly about their marriage. He still wasn't happy with it, but he'd still allowed Fez to come over for Thanksgiving dinner with the rest of the family. He still had to sit at the kids table with Hyde, Kelso and Jackie, and she had to sit with the adults - not to mention a visiting Eric and Donna - but it was progress.

Her thoughts floated back to Thanksgiving. She'd really made a pig of herself during that. So much turkey, stuffing, corn, potatoes... She was pretty sure she ate an entire pumpkin pie by herself! If only she had the money to eat that much every day.

If only so she could enjoy having Fez give her a belly rub on her bed, as he had that evening. It had been so sexy - they'd just laid back in silence, both of them half-asleep from turkey, and he'd just gently rubbed her stomach until she fell asleep. And when she woke up the next morning, he was still there, conked out, with his hand still on her tummy. If there hadn't been a fear of Red finding them, she would've stayed like that forever.

She slipped a sweater on - a green one with a red and white pattern, and she took a moment to appreciate the way it hugged her curves. Her boobs were way bigger with all this weight, making her belly just a little less noticeable. She may be content with her growing girth, but that didn't mean she wanted a whole bunch of high school bozos mocking her. Especially when Jackie's pep squad were going to be the center of attention all night. Those girls were merciless.
